data.body:
- cocos2d-x version: 3.13.1
- devices test on: iphone 6
- developing environments
  - NDK version: N/A
  - Xcode version: 8.0
  - VS version: N/A
  - browser type and version: N/A

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Play a looping background music & a looping effect in HelloWorldLayer

``` C++
    SimpleAudioEngine::getInstance()->playBackgroundMusic("fonts/background.mp3", true);
    SimpleAudioEngine::getInstance()->playEffect("fonts/effect1.wav", true);
```
1. Press `home` button
2. Go back to foreground by double click `home` button and select the game.
3. The effect may not be resumed.

data.title: Sprites with alpha look darker when being animated
data.body:
We noticed that in our game sprites with alpha looked darker and ended up finding out that it was an issue with premultiplied alpha.

cocos2d-x will by default premultiply every RGBA8888 texture, in our case we saw that the darker sprites problem appeared only on sprites that were being animated with the Animate action.

In the issue https://github.com/cocos2d/cocos2d-x/issues/93673 was added two lines to CCAnimate

```
 auto blend = static_cast<Sprite*>(_target)->getBlendFunc(); //THIS LINE
 _currFrameIndex = i;
 AnimationFrame* frame = frames.at(_currFrameIndex);
 frameToDisplay = frame->getSpriteFrame();
 static_cast<Sprite*>(_target)->setSpriteFrame(frameToDisplay);
 static_cast<Sprite*>(_target)->setBlendFunc(blend);  //THIS LINE
```

what those lines do is force the blendfunc to the one configured in the sprite ignoring the proper blendfunc determined by the current sprite frame texture.

In the test project you can see one case where the effect is rendered correctly, and one when the effect is rendered darker.

The difference between those two cases is that in the one that renders correctly the sprite is initialised with the first frame of the animation, so the blend func is consistent while the animation is running.

In the case that renders incorrectly the sprite is first created empty without referencing the animation sprites, and after that an Animate action is executed. In this case the sprite has ALPHA_NON_PREMULTIPLIED but the texture needs ALPHA_PREMULTIPLIED to be rendered correctly, and the Animate action will force ALPHA_NON_PREMULTIPLIED to be used.

We think this change is a big change in how cocos2d-x used to work and in our case, we almost always create an empty sprite and afterwards we set it up with an animation if needed.
If this remains we will need to either disable premultiplication, comment the lines in CCAnimate or change everywhere we create sprites to use the first sprite which is a worse match for how our engine works.

We created a small test project with this so you can test.
https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B88Hp_AZaft0QW8xYjhrZGN4aWc

![045f6c71888088fee8238da5be1271f159d5dd06](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12350808/19623450/b8879924-989f-11e6-833f-966510f0b2cd.png)

data.title: Confused Matrix Name
data.body:
Reported at http://discuss.cocos2d-x.org/t/cc-mvmatrix-help/20974

> Figured it out. Turns out CC_MVMatrix is just the model matrix & CC_PMatrix is the view-projection matrix. Those names are pretty mis-leading!

I think the developer in the forum is correct. We have used wrong names for `model(world), view, projection` matrix.

data.title: bug + fix on setAdditionalTransform( nullptr )
android-build.py doesn't work if Android API level 13 is not installed
data.body:
cocos2d-x/build$ ./android-build.py cpp-empty-test
cocos compile -p android -s /Users/poluektov/devel/playground/cocos2d/cocos2d-x/build/../tests/cpp-empty-test --ndk-mode debug --app-abi armeabi-v7a
Building mode: debug
Using Eclipse project : /Users/poluektov/devel/playground/cocos2d/cocos2d-x/tests/cpp-empty-test/proj.android
**The directory 'android-13' can't be found in ANDROID_SDK_ROOT/platforms, please use --ap to set needed API level**
Build dynamic library for project [ /Users/poluektov/devel/playground/cocos2d/cocos2d-x/build/../tests/cpp-empty-test ] fails!

I addressed this issue in this PR: https://github.com/cocos2d/cocos2d-x/pull/16727

(I also changed a bunch of other things in the script, like replacing deprecated OptionParser with ArgumentParser, PEP8-zing the code, and some other small improvements).

data.title: Add support for pitch with new audio engine playback

data.title: Fix android-build.py
data.body:
Fixes various problems with android-build.py:
- allows to specify android API level (to propagate to '--ap' flag of cocos console tool)
- fixes help messages
- replaces deprecated OptionParser with ArgumentParser
- simplifies the code

data.title: [Don't merge]VRSDK modification list
Support MultiView matrix array
data.body: Support MultiView matrix array and add new interface in GLProgram to support shader header definitions.

data.title: Mesh generates access violation in Vertexbuffer on second Draw() call
data.body:
- cocos2d-x version:  3.13.1
- devices test on: Windows 10
- developing environments
  - VS version: 2013 Community

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a mesh inside a class derived from Node, with an override Draw()
2. Retain the mesh
3. Add the instance of the derived class into a Scene with AddChild
4. Try to access mesh->getVertexBuffer() inside the second call to overriden Draw()

This will throw an access violation. Other attributes of mesh remain correct, including the indexBuffer, but not the vertexBuffer.

A more extensive explanation can be found in this forum post: [http://discuss.cocos2d-x.org/t/custom-draw-not-working-on-mesh-object/32748](url)
The code is based on this one found in the wiki: [http://www.cocos2d-x.org/wiki/3D_Graphics#Building-a-Mesh](url)

A minimal example of the offending code is attached here:
[MeshProblem.zip](https://github.com/cocos2d/cocos2d-x/files/538839/MeshProblem.zip)

If you need something else, just ask.

data.title: RenderState::bind(Pass* pass), the `pass` argument is never used
(iOS) Crash after receive applicationDidReceiveMemoryWarning
data.body:
The reason caused crash is "on applicationDidReceiveMemoryWarning  function exist code calling cocos2d::Director::getInstance()->purgeCachedData();"

Steps to Reproduce:
1. add texturePack with 3 sprite frames: A,B, C
2. create sprite with sprite-frame A, B
3. cocos2d::Director::getInstance()->purgeCachedData(); (simulate like function applicationDidReceiveMemoryWarning )
4. create sprite with sprite frame C
   ==> sprite frame C won't exist  ==> crash from "Assert Failed! spriteFrame can't be nullptr!"

data.title: Should `Node` be located in `cocos2d-x/cocos/base` directory?
data.body:
Currently, it's in `cocos2d-x/cocos/2d` directory, but `Sprite3D` is also inherited from `Node`.
Our `Node` isn't a 2D node anymore. IMO, it should be located in `cocos2d-x/cocos/base` directory.

data.title: Fixes label wrong blending and improves performance while enabling outline.
data.body:
The old outline shader will cause wrong blending while enabling outline for label.
You could refer to the following screenshot to compare.

The old label display:

![old](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/493372/19463652/703155ae-9528-11e6-9fe7-3fb04a0d808b.png)

The label after this fix:
![after-fix](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/493372/19463653/712577d8-9528-11e6-937b-bbb9279b403e.png)

Please notice the blue color and its alpha depth.

The Reproduced Code:

``` c++
    auto label = Label::createWithTTF("Hello World", "fonts/arial.ttf", 70);

    // position the label on the center of the screen
    label->setPosition(origin.x + visibleSize.width/2,
                            origin.y + visibleSize.height - label->getContentSize().height);

    label->enableOutline(Color4B(0, 255, 0, 100), 10); // Set 100 alpha for outline
    label->setTextColor(Color4B(0, 0, 255, 100)); // Also set 100 alpha for text
    // add the label as a child to this layer
    this->addChild(label, 1);
```

For more easily to find this blending problem, you could set both outline and text color to green, and see the difference.

The old outline shader:

![screen shot 2016-10-18 at 11 57 23](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/493372/19463887/5175c2a6-952a-11e6-8b66-2810e9c749d7.png)

The new outline shader:

![screen shot 2016-10-18 at 12 00 22](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/493372/19463910/7be04bb0-952a-11e6-889f-0475a5e5157d.png)

data.title: Performance tweak: Use range-based for-loops and allocate std::vector size() and *end() on the stack where favorable.
data.body:
Basically this is the same as #16642, but on a bigger scale. All the files changed in this pull request were identified by using the following commands in Linux:

```
$ cd "${COCOS_GIT_ROOT}"/cocos
$ find . -type f -exec grep -Iq . {} \; -and -print0 | xargs -0 grep -P "^\s*for\s*\(.*end\s*\(|^\s*for\s*\(.*size\s*\(|^\s*while\s*\(.*end\s*\(|^\s*while\s*\(.*size\s*\("
```

The only files that I didn't take a look at were those under the `cocos/editor-support`, `cocos/deprecated` and `cocos/scripting` directories, but they can be identified by using the above commands.

data.title: ui::Scrollview doesn't work in Android Emulator
data.body:
- cocos2d-x version: 3.13.1
- devices test on: Android Emulator (Nexus 5X API 24 x86)
- developing environments
  - NDK version: r13
  - Android Studio version: 2.2.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a ui::ScrollView with an InnerContainerSize larger than the ContentSize and add it to a scene.
2. Run the app in Android Emulator.

On iOS these ScrollViews work just fine, and they're also fine on Android hardware, but they don't work in the emulator. Here's a screenshot of how they look in the emulator.

![screenshot_1476717271](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1251092/19443484/e6f9e102-945a-11e6-8645-a44ac4335d60.png)

The entire green area should be transparent and show a nice background, and the white areas below and above should also be transparent and show through to the background.

data.title: using arguments caused low perfomance on jsb
data.body:
- cocos2d-x version: >=3.10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. onEnter: function () {
       this._super();
       this.scheduleUpdate();
   },
   
   update: function (delta) {
       var fn = function(){
           arguments; //this line caused very low performance on jsb
       };
       var t = Date.now();
       for (var i=0;i<10000;i++)
       {
           fn();
       }
       cc.log("total time: " + (Date.now() - t));
   }
2.

data.title: Fix typos in local variables
data.body: This pull request fixes some minor typos in local variables. It also doesn't break backward compatibility. Thanks!

data.title: Mesh* Sprite3D::getMesh() should return nullptr when _meshes.empty() is true
data.body: So we check _meshes.empty() before return.
